Now is one of the best times in the last five or six years to invest in a home purchase in Northern Virginia. Hereâ€™s why.

Today we are only going to talk about one thing, buying and holding. In other words, real estate property investment. I think this is the season to do it for many reasons.

If youâ€™re looking to buy and flip a home, that time has passed. However, right now is arguably one of the best times in the last five or six years to buy an investment property in Northern Virginia for a few reasons. Here they are:

1. Money is cheap. I recently bought an investment property with a rate under 4.5%. If you look at rates historically, they have never really been this low for investment properties. Iâ€™ve seen cheap rates across the board. When youâ€™re buying and holding, the rate is even more important than the price. If youâ€™re holding a property long-term, your tenant/s will be paying that down over time anyways.

2. Winter offers and winter sellers. Winter offers tend to be a little bit more aggressive and winter sellers tend to be a little bit more desperate when selling. Right now, there are investors out there that have to move properties in order to get another property or to liquidate assets. This plays to your advantage as well.

3. The options you have. What kind of property should you buy? It all depends on your situation. Iâ€™m a hands-on landlord, so I like to invest in townhomes and multi-family properties. However, your plan may be completely different. You should sit down with someone, like us, who can help you determine what your situation is and what your goals are.

4. Cash on cash return. How much do you want to get back from your investment? We can sit down with you and calculate that number. The rule of thumb with me is to look at the rate of return you can get through investing in real estate vs. the rate of return you get from your bank. When you put your money into a CD or mutual account, you might only get a 1% or 2% rate of return. With investment properties, however, Iâ€™m seeing a 7% to 8% cash on cash return with regularity in Northern Virginia. In addition to those returns, you have appreciation. That raises your cash on cash return even higher.

If you have money sitting around somewhere and itâ€™s not getting the return you want, you would be foolish not to look at real estate investing here in Northern Virginia. We just settled a deal yesterday for one of our clients who bought his 10th property with the AJ Team. He has reaped the benefits greatly.

If you or someone you know is thinking about investing, give us a call or send us an email. We want to help you build your wealth.

entry.title: 2 More Things to Consider in a Trump Presidency
entry.content:
How Trump Will Affect the Real Estate Market- Part 2 from AJ Team LLC on Vimeo.

President-elect Donald Trump has expressed a desire to increase defense spending. What will happen with our local real estate market if he does?

There are a lot of things weâ€™ll need to keep an eye on during Donald Trumpâ€™s presidency in terms of real estate. Here are two more factors weâ€™ll need to pay close attention to over the next four years:

1. Real estate is local. It has always been about local real estate. What happens here is very different than what happens in the Midwest. Our economy is greatly influenced by big government and government spending. Donald Trump has talked about spending more money on the department of defense. If he does that, it means the economy is going to benefit in our area. If those things come to fruition, expect local real estate to see a jump.

2. Foreign money. On the flip side, President-elect Trump talked about being tougher on immigration. There are a lot of immigrants here in the area and a lot of international money, too. If foreign investors start to get skittish, they wonâ€™t be spending as much in the local economy and they may decide to make other investments instead.

Those are two important local real estate factors you should pay attention to. Think back to the market crash in 2008 and what happened in Prince William County. Immigration policy changed, the market crashed, and look what happened there.

There are plenty of things you can giveâ€”anything helps. We like to give the parents time to give these gifts to their kids, so we love for you to hustle up with us and help us give a happy holiday to some families in need.

If you have any questions about how to help, give us a call or send us an email. We look forward to hearing from you!

link.title: Would You Help Us Be a Blessing to Families in Need?

entry.title: Why Do Home Sellers Need to Look at Interest Rates?
entry.content:
Interest rates may go up soon, and home buyers arenâ€™t the only ones who will be affected. Today Iâ€™ll go over everything sellers need to know about interest rates and home value.

Realtors always talk about how interest rates affect home buyers. Today, however, weâ€™re going to focus on how interest rates affect your ability to sell a property. 

First of all, you need to know the 1%, 10% rule. If interest rates go up by 1%, home values go down by 10%. On the other hand, if interest rates go down 1%, home values will rise 10%. 

If interest rates go up by 1%, your home value will go down 10%

Right now, interest rates are at 3.5%. If your home is currently worth $500,000 and rates go up to 4.5%, you will lose 10% off of your home value. In other words, your home value will go down by $50,000. Most people donâ€™t talk about the 1%, 10% rule for home sellers, but itâ€™s something you need to keep in mind if you are considering selling your home. 

Here is a quick history lesson for you: in 2013, interest rates were at 4.5%. During 2008, the bottom of the market, interest rates were at 6%. Now, I donâ€™t think that rates will skyrocket and drastically impact the economy in the next 12 months. However, I do think that 3.5% interest rate will look very different at this time next year. 

If you are selling your home, you also need to consider how interest rates will affect your buyer. If interest rates go up, your potential buyerâ€™s mortgage payment will go up. Not only that, they may not be able to afford your house if the 3.5% interest rate goes up. If you are looking to sell your property, I recommend selling when rates are low so that more people can afford your home and your home value will go up. 

Finally, here in Northern Virginia, there are not many cash buyers in our market. Roughly 95% of people buying homes in our market use some kind of financing, so you need to consider interest rates and the value of your home when deciding whether or not to sell. 

If you have any other questions about interest rates or selling your home in the current market, give me a call or send me an email. I would be happy to help you!

link.title: Why Do Home Sellers Need to Look at Interest Rates?

entry.title: How Do You Know When to Sell Your Home?
entry.content:
Most people think that the best time of year to sell is in the spring or summer, but that is not necessarily true. There are three factors you should consider before putting your home on the market.

When is the best time to sell your home? Most people think that the best time of year to sell is in the spring or summer, but that is not necessarily true for all markets.   

If you are trying to figure out when to sell your home, there are a few things you should consider:  
  1. What are your neighbors doing? If all of your neighbors are waiting until spring to put your home on the market, that means your competition will go up in the spring. Generally, when competition goes up, home prices tend to go down.
    1. Pay attention to pricing and positioning. Make sure you price and position your home properly in the market. As far as positioning, it can be beneficial to be on the market when most of your neighbors are not. You should also make sure that your home is priced competitively for the market.
    1. What kind of home are you selling? Are you selling a condo, a single-family home, or a townhome? Depending on what kind of property you are selling, you will be working to attract a different kind of buyer.
    For example, if you are selling a single-family home, the buyer you are looking for will probably have kids. The buyerâ€™s schedule may be governed by when school is open and when school is closed, so you need to make sure that your home is available when that buyer is able to make a move.   

    If you are selling a condo or townhome, your buyer may be young and single, or married with kids that are too young to be in school. These buyers move when their leases are up, when they save enough money, or when interest rates are low enough that they can afford the property.   As you can see, part of putting your home on the market is considering the buyerâ€™s profile. You need to understand your ideal buyer and when they will be able to move.    

    So, when youâ€™re thinking about the best time to sell your home, donâ€™t just focus on the season. There are plenty of other factors to pay attention to.   In other news, We recently moved our office right in the middle of Lake Ridge, and we are excited to be here. We have even heard some rumblings that HGTV is filming in the area! Weâ€™ll go into more detail on that later. If you have any questions about preparing your home for the market or about real estate in general, give us a call or send us an email.

link.title: How Do You Know When to Sell Your Home?

entry.title: Tips for Maximizing the Value of Your Home
entry.content:
I get calls all the time from clients who say, â€œIâ€™m ready to list my home on the market. What should I do to prepare it?â€Iâ€™d like to answer this question with a quick story. About ten years ago, I was working with a client who had already spent $20,000 remodeling the kitchen in her home in order to get it ready to be sold. Though the kitchen looked nice, she wasnâ€™t prepared to spend much more on the renovations that I would have suggested she make. 

At the closing table, this client asked the buyer about the first thing that he was planning to do when he moved into her home. The buyer responded, â€œThe first thing Iâ€™m going to do is rip out and remodel that kitchen!â€ The lesson here is to realize that your tastes wonâ€™t necessarily match the tastes of a potential buyer. 

This is why rule number one when it comes to preparing your house for the market is to make smart renovations. You will not always see a return on every single dollar you put into your property upon selling it. If you put $50,000 into a renovation, that does not necessarily equal $50,000 in added value. Make sure you understand your budget. 

My second tip to prepare your home for the market is simply to paint. This is a very quick, easy, and cost-effective way to add value to your home. When painting, though, be sure to paint in neutral colors. Hereâ€™s an advanced painting tip: If youâ€™re wondering what kinds of colors are the best ones to use to paint, go to your builder or a model home like yours and use the colors that theyâ€™re using. These companies spend thousands of dollars on designers that know much more about paint colors than you or I do, and those are the color palettes that most buyers want to see. Itâ€™s also crucial to paint your front door. The front door is one of the first things that potential buyers will notice in the moments before they enter the home. 

"The front door is one of the first things that potential buyers will notice..."


Replacing your front door is a very smart move for the same reason. Make sure that your front entrance provides the ambiance necessary to open up the rest of the home in the eyes of the buyer.Finally, if youâ€™re wondering whether you should make necessary repairs before you list your home, the answer is always yes. There is, however, a major difference between making a necessary repair and getting a cosmetic upgrade. 

Anything that needs to be fixed, like a malfunctioning sink, a leaky roof, or a foundational issue, should be repaired immediately. Buyers will find out about those issues during the home inspection anyway, so make sure that those repairs are made ahead of time. If you have any other questions about getting your home ready for the market, donâ€™t hesitate to reach out to me by phone or email. Remember, you have the dream; we have the address.

link.title: Tips for Maximizing the Value of Your Home

entry.title: Join Us in the 2016 Backpack Challenge!
entry.content:
We've always been big advocates of supporting the local community, and this time, we wanted to give you the chance to help us out with the Community Backpack Challenge 2016. We're excited to invite you to help us set our local youth up for success in the future. We're collecting pre-filled backpacks for elementary and middle school aged kids, starting now! We'll collect backpacks all the way up to the end of August. You can drop off contributions at our Keller Williams Alexandria office, 6408 Grovedale Dr. #101, Alexandria, VA 22192. You can also drop off at Tropical Smoothie Woodbridge, or set up a personal pick-up if you give us a call or send us an email. Ideas for included supplies include:
  • Wide-rule notebooks
  • Crayons (24 box)
  • Glue sticks
  • #2 pencils
  • Colored Pencils
  • Pencil box
  • Plastic folders
  • Glue bottle
  • Pencil sharpener
  • Washable markers
  • Yellow highlighter
  • Large erasers
  • Wide-ruled paper
  • Three-ring binder
  • Blue, black, and red pens
  • Ruler
Thank you so much for joining us as we help support the local school community! If you have any further questions, please feel free to give us a call or send us an email. We hope to see you soon!

entry.title: What Is Happening in the Northern Virginia Real Estate Market?
entry.content:
â€œIs it a buyerâ€™s or sellerâ€™s market?â€ I get that question all the time, and itâ€™s a loaded question. In Northern Virginia, we kind of live in a bubble; our real estate reality is not the same as the rest of the nationâ€™s. Letâ€™s dive into some numbers so you can be proactive about your real estate decisions instead of reactive. The average days on market right now is 40 days. If youâ€™re out in tertiary markets, the suburbs, or Loudoun, that number is a bit higher. If youâ€™re in Alexandria, Arlington, or Annandale, that number is a bit lower. The X factor that determines whether weâ€™re in a buyerâ€™s or sellerâ€™s market is actually the price of your money. Interest rates were expected to go a bit higher this year but rates have actually gone down. Right now, rates are hovering around 3.5%. To put that in perspective, the lowest rates ever recorded were low to mid threeâ€™s in 2012.
"Low interest rates have spurred the market on and made homes more affordable."
We didnâ€™t see these interest rates coming, but they have spurred the market on and made homes a bit more affordable. If youâ€™re thinking of moving up into a different property, buying your first home, or investing in real estate, now is a great time to get into the market. Thanks to all of the political uncertainty in our country, you will see rates stay this low until we know whoâ€™s going into office. Now is the time to get into the real estate market. If you have any questions, give me a call or send me an email. I would be happy to help you!
